Legal_Issue: Can Nycomed amend its counterclaim to allege contributory infringement by Apotex and Novopharm?
Legal_Rule: The General Rule states that selling an article not infringing itself does not constitute patent infringement unless it falls under two exceptions: (a) selling all components of the invention for assembly, or (b) knowingly inducing procurement of infringement. The court applies the stringent three-prong Inducement Test for contributory infringement.
Grounds_for_Claim: Allegation of contributory infringement by Apotex and Novopharm
Outcome_on_Merits: Contributory inducement is not a reasonable cause of action; claim rejected
Applicant_Challenge: Nycomed sought to amend its counterclaim
Defendant_Response: Apotex and Novopharm opposed the amendment
Remedy_Requested: Amendment of counterclaim to include contributory infringement
Outcome: Amendment not allowed; costs awarded to Apotex and Novopharm
Authority: Prothonotary Milczynski (initial decision), Federal Court (appellate review)
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Failure to meet the three-prong Inducement Test; lack of legal basis for contributory inducement claim
Applicable_Process: Amendment of pleadings in federal litigation
Governing_Rule: The General Rule on contributory patent infringement and the Inducement Test
